citation.article-title: Syntrophothermus lipocalidus gen. nov., sp. nov., a novel thermophilic, syntrophic, fatty-acid-oxidizing anaerobe which utilizes isobutyrate.
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Syntrophothermus (Syn.tro.pho.ther'mus. Gr. adj. syn together with; Gr. fem. n. trophos one who feeds; Gr. adj. thermus hot; M.L. masc. n. Syntrophothermus thermophilic syntrophic bacterium, referring to growth in syntrophic association with hydrogenotrophic organisms at high temperatures of around 55 °C)
Cells are slightly curved rods, Gram-reaction negative, weakly motile, and obligately anaerobic.
The organisms grow optimally at high temperatures of around 55 °C and at nearly neutral pH.
Only fatty acids, including butyrate and higher homologues, are utilized in syntrophic association with hydrogen-utilizing microbes.
On the basis of the 16S rDNA phylogeny, the genus Syntrophothermus belongs to the family Syntrophomonadaceae.
The DNA base composition is 51.0 mol%.
G+­C (determined by HPLC). Syntrophothermus lipocalidus is the type species of the genus.
